content.text: When the string is displaced by a small angle from the vertical, the height of the cylinder changes so that its centre of mass is now \(1.932 \text{m}\) below the pivot. Determine the gravitational potential energy gained by the cylinder. Use \(g = 10 \text{m/s}^2\)
The cylinder is released from the displaced position in **(a)**. Calculate the expected speed of the cylinder when the string is vertical
expected speed = .........
Calculate the actual speed of the cylinder
actual speed =
Suggest how the difference between the actual and expected speeds could occur

Fig. 1.1 shows a simple pendulum being used by a student to investigate the energy various points in the pendulum's swing
The car approaches a corner and decelerates from \(82 \text{m/s}\) to \(61 \text{m/s}\) in \(0.90 \text{s}\)
Calculate the deceleration
deceleration = .........
The energy lost during the braking in **(a)** is \(8.4 \times 10^{5} \text{J}\). \(40\%\) of this lost energy is directed to the KERS system. Determine the amount of energy stored
energy stored =
The driver later uses all of this stored energy to give \(60\mathrm{kW}\) of useful extra power for 3.0 s. Calculate the energy released
energy released =
Calculate the efficiency of the KERS system
efficiency =
Suggest a possible device to store energy when a moving vehicle slows down. For state the change that occurs as more energy is stored
device
change
The racing car shown in Fig. 2.1 uses a Kinetic Energy Recovery System (KERS)
stores within the car some of the kinetic energy lost when the car slows down for a driver can later release the stored energy when maximum power is required

In the production of X-rays, the target gets very hot. Thermal energy must be removed from the target. The tube has several design features to enable this to happen
